H0.text: The time to begin is the information another student would most likely need to perform the same experiment measuring how long it would take for a cup of water to freeze.

H1.text: The volume of the cup is the information another student would most likely need to perform the same experiment to determine how long it takes for a cup of water to freeze.

H2.text: The temperature of the ice is the information another student would most likely need to perform the same experiment to determine how long a cup of water takes to freeze.

H3.text: The type of thermometer to use is the information another student most likely needs to perform the experiment measuring how long a cup of water takes to freeze.

A4.text: The freezing point of a solvent is depressed when another compound is added, meaning that a solution has a lower freezing point than a pure solvent.

A5.text: Today, containerless laser heating techniques, combined with fast pyrometers and spectro-pyrometers, are employed to allow for precise control of the time for which the sample is kept at extreme temperatures.

A6.text: The freezing point of water is 0 Â°C at atmospheric pressure at sea level.

A7.text: The length of a column of mercury, confined in a glass-walled capillary tube, is dependent largely on temperature and is the basis of the very useful mercury-in-glass thermometer.

A8.text: Once it freezes and becomes ice, it expands by about 9%, with a density of 917 kg/m3 (57.25 lb/cu ft).

A9.text: Water boils at lower temperatures with the lower air pressure that occurs at higher elevations.
